learning_outcomes.description: Explain the structure and function of cells, including organelles and macromolecules, as foundations of life.
Describe energy flow in biological systems, including photosynthesis and cellular respiration.
Summarise principles of genetics, inheritance, and reproduction in living organisms.
Outline the diversity of life and evolutionary principles underpinning biological classification.
Describe core ecological concepts, including organism-environment interactions, energy transfer, and ecosystem dynamics.
Critically analyse and interpret biological data using digital and visual tools, including the ethical use of Artificial Intelligence (AI), to evaluate scientific evidence.

Recognise how biological knowledge, including Indigenous knowledges and perspectives of Country, informs debates on conservation, environment, and human impacts, fostering inclusive and culturally aware understanding.

assessments.task_description:
Over the course of the semester, you will complete 9 x 10 minute multiple choice questionnaires. You will complete one quiz per week during workshop time in all weeks EXCEPT weeks 1, 5, 9, 10. These quizzes will be at start of your workshop, and we will take the best SIX out of the NINE quizzes to calculate your final grade for this assessment. Each quiz is worth 5%.

Each quiz will target the course content from the week before. So for example, in week 2, you will be tested on your knowledge and comprehension of week 1. These quizzes will also serve as valuable revisions for your end of semester exam and indicate content areas where perhaps you need more guidance and support.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You will complete the quiz under exam conditions. The quiz will be accessed through the BIOL1000 Blackboard Ultra website. To access the quiz, you will be provided a password. The test will only be open for 15 min during the first 15 min of class time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.assessment_title: Inquiry and Synthesis in the AI Era - Part 1: Written
assessments.task_description:
Part 1 of this assessment is a written component. This assessment develops your ability to locate, evaluate, and synthesise scientific literature using AI tools. You will be given a topic, build a focused reference list, justify your source choices, summarize key papers, and demonstrate understanding through in-class responses. AI tools are integrated to support, but not replace, your critical thinking and writing.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You submit your link through a Turnitin link accessed through your BIOL1000 course Blackboard site
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Inquiry and Synthesis in the AI Era – Part 2: In-Class assessment
assessments.task_description:
Part 2 of this assessment is a an in-class assessment . This assessment develops your ability to locate, evaluate, and synthesise scientific literature using AI tools. You will be given a topic, build a focused reference list, justify your source choices, summarize key papers, and demonstrate understanding through in-class responses. AI tools are integrated to support, but not replace, your critical thinking and writing.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This is an end of semester exam where you will be asked to answer a series of questions on ANY of the content covered during the 13 weeks.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures (Module 1)

Each week you will attend a 2 hour interactive lecture.

Module 1 = Responding to change in the cellular environment.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures (Module 1) Each week you will attend a 2 hour interactive lecture. Module 1 = Responding to change in the cellular environment.

learning_activities.topic:
Workshops (Module 1)

Each week you will also attend a 2 hour workshop where you will be guided through activities related to the corresponding week's lecture. These workshops have been designed to help you understand key concepts. In week 1, you will be given a workbook, which you are expected to fill out during your workshop time. These workbooks are not graded, but will be an excellent revision guide for the final exam (the course hurdle). Hence, the more work and detail you put into your workbook, the more detailed revision guide you will have!

In week 1 we will also discuss how to start work on your AI assessment.

Weeks 2,3,4 will start with your MCQ quiz.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L06

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures (Module 2)

This lecture is the start of Module 2 - Responding to Change in the Natural Environment. This module will be lead by Dr. Nicola Browne.


Learning outcomes: L05, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures (Module 2) This lecture is the start of Module 2 - Responding to Change in the Natural Environment. This module will be lead by Dr. Nicola Browne.

learning_activities.topic:
Workshops (Module 2)

Over these four weeks, you will complete three MCQs at the start of workshops 6, 7 and 8. In week 5, you will also be provided time to work on your AI assessment and seek feedback on your progress.


Learning outcomes: L05, L06

learning_activities.topic:
Revision lecture

Revision lecture

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L07

Final workshop

In this final workshop you will complete part of your AI assessment. There will also be time for reflection on your workbooks and feedback on how to improve your workbooks to enhance this revision tool for your end of semester exam.

Learning outcomes: L06, L07
